body: @afchung @yunseong This looks good to me.

Hi, @zerg-junior . 
I left a comment on JIRA, https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1108?focusedCommentId=15106047&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15106047 .
Hi, @markusweimer . Could you merge this PR if you have some spare-time? :)
@yunseong I've addressed the missed comment, please have another look. Thanks!
@afchung Thanks. This looks great. I'll merge it.
Merged
@afchung Congratulations for taking a greatly lucky PR number. :) I'll take a look.
@afchung The changes look great and straightforward. I've left minor comments though. Could you take a look at them? Thanks!
I'll have a look.
@dongjoon-hyun Thanks for the PR! I believe the standard XML documentation header for C# should use line-comments instead of block comments though (i.e. '//' instead of '/*').
@yunseong Thanks for the review! I've addressed your comments, please have another look.

Thank you, @afchung . The main purpose of this PR is using the same format for the Apache License Header. As you know, we are using three types now. (And some file have problems, too). Do you mean to make them all uniformly with '//'?

By the way, recently, we are moving to `Doxygen` for .Net documentation. `Doxygen` will confuse with the javadoc style ('/**') Apache License Header. So, I think '/*' is the best choice for use.

Should we use '//' for .Net and '/*' for Java? That kind of guideline also sounds good to me.

The changes seem fine to me, I left some minor comments.

I am quite confused about the use of `Time` in Wake.NET. I will start a thread on the dev list for that.
@jwang98052 could you have another look?
I've renamed the file and removed comments.
I'm partial to using '//' for .NET and '/*' for Java. From what I can see, using '//' for .NET seems to be standard.
+1 to @afchung's suggestion  ReSharper generates file header with `//` which a lot of people use with Visual Studio for .NET development. Moving to `/*` will be a hassle.
No problem at all, @afchung  and @anupam128 . I'll give my +1 for that, too. I'll change the JIRA issue and this PR for that. Thank you, @afchung  and @anupam128 .

+1 to whatever format makes Doxygen recognize the license as a comment and not as documentation

Note to merger: a 1000-file PR is likely to cause our mirroring daemon to get stuck. To un-stuck, commit another change on top of this one.
It looks good to me and tested on Mac/Ubuntu/Windows and docker-based Yarn. I will merge this.

This change removes the static cache in Tang. How much does this impact performance? Overall, I am +1 for this change and I don't like static caches in classes that can potentially be accessed in multiple threads, but I'm not sure what the original design decision was. If we want to keep the static cache, it seems like we're not locking properly either in `ClassHierarchyImpl`. In Java, all the methods are locked via synchronized while in C# the methods are locked with 3 different locks.
I'll merge this based on majority opinion and passing tests :-)
Thank you for your understanding, @tcNickolas !

I rebased and make this PR as a part 1 (in order to avoid getting stuck).
I will make subsequent PRs soon.

One option to reduce number of PRs without getting stuck is split this one in just 2 parts: one with most files, and second with only 1 or 2 files. The first one will get stuck, but the second one will fix it. 100 files are not guaranteed to not get stuck
Oh, I got it!
@afchung @markusweimer made changes. Please take a look.
Sorry, but I'm still working on this according to the @tcNickolas 's advice.
@anupam128 I'm done with another pass. Thanks!

@afchung I've done another pass, and made some minor comments/questions (in your repo). Please have a look. I think this is good to be merged once I hear your answers. 
@bgchun Do you have any comment?
Hi, I've finished all. This PR has major parts and https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/780 has a small part to close REEF-1135.
The number of total changed files decreased and `Doxygen` (of #773) ignores the Apache License Header correctly. Thank you all.

Now, it looks good to me except the inclusion of the Apache License Header and the lack of documentation contents. To publish on the web, this PR at least needs #775 and #780 . If you don't mind, could you hold the generation and publishing until #775 and #780 are merged?
Yes, of course I'll wait for that change. I consider release 0.14 a hard deadline for finalizing .NET apidocs on the website, so we still have 2 weeks

Okay, then I'll merge this PR right now. The PR looks good to me. `Doxygen` has proper settings and it generates docs based on the current codes well. We can continue further stuffs base on this except publishing during 2 weeks.

## NAVER - http://www.naver.com/

fatalu1226@naver.com 님께 보내신 메일 <Re: [reef] [REEF-113] Integrate .NET API documentation with our website, part 1 (#773)> 이 다음과 같은 이유로 전송 실패했습니다.

---

받는 사람이 회원님의 메일을 수신차단 하였습니다. 

---

@yunseong I'm fairly sure that using `ConcurrentMap` makes the class thread safe, given that it is the only object in the class. We need to make the `AggregateFunctionRepository` thread safe because both `RunningWorkers` and `DefaultVortexMaster` are accessing it, potentially in different threads, and we can't control it with a single lock object.

@yunseong I've fixed the warning. Thanks!
Sorry. There was an error in my mailing server.

@afchung @yunseong Looks good.
It'd be good to have client-side examples with and without local aggregation in another PR.
@bgchun Thanks for the comment. I agree that it'd be great to show some examples once we have end-to-end functionality. For now, I'll merge this.

ClassHIerarchy is a tree and keeps growing. If the code shares the same assemblies, sharing class hierarchy would have better performance. On another hand, we try to make configuration immutable and do deep copy whenever a new configuration is built. With this in mind, we probably don't want to share the class hierarchy instance as well. 
Ultimately we should make the internal data structure in the class hierarchy thread safe. Currently we use readwrite lock for adding a node. We should use the same lock for read as well. I have open a Jira REEF-1140 for it.
We might be able to make TreeTopology  and  FlatTopology  class internal. All the three methods are already exposed in the interface. The constructors are mainly used in the project.
OK, as long as the users have a way to specify what they want, I'll make it internal.
git diff shows that a lot of files has changed encoding (first line has a rectangle as first character). Can this be reverted? I think we aim to have one encoding across all files.

Do you mean the BOM, 'U+FEFF'? Actually, I preserved the encoding like this. 
- lang/cs/Org.Apache.REEF.All/Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs

```
-<U+FEFF>/**
- * Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
...
+<U+FEFF>// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
```
- lang/cs/Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge/ActiveContextClr2Java.cpp

```
-/**
- * Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
+// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
```

I think some of CS file generated in Windows OS have BOM. So, I didn't change anything. You can see the difference between the above two files.
The above is the result of `git diff master` in Mac. Maybe, in Windows, do you see _rectangle_? Then, I'll check my PR in Windows, too.
@anupam128 Seems like there are test failures, could you take another look?
Yes, I'm on Windows, and I see rectangle where there used to be none. Not in all files, but, for example, in `Org.Apache.REEF.All/Properties/AssemblyInfo.cs`

Ur, I'm on Windows 10 now and the result is the same for me.

```

index 0897d80..7791b70 100644

@@ -1,21 +1,19 @@

- * specific language governing permissions and limitations
- * under the License.
- */
+<U+FEFF>// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
...
```

So, from discussion on JIRA it looks like there should be no effect for ASA, if code gets default class hierarchy exactly once the behavior doesn't change (it's 2nd and following instantiations that are affected)
Any other comments before we can merge?
As expected, mirroring stuck at merging this. Proceeding to #780
Oh, your approach handles this correctly! Thank you, @tcNickolas .

I thought the point of this work is to change the way errors are handled, to improve it? I don't think it makes a lot of sense to preserve everything and configure the checks just to configure each violation to ignore them. Suppressions should be used only for real false positives

Also, now there are conflicts in this branch. Could you please resolve them?

@afchung Will you take this across the finish line? I'm +1 on merging this.
Looks good to me, I will test and merge.

This change passes `mvn clean test` for me (doesn't pass without the change).

Is `test` the best phase to create jar files in? Maybe something like `generate-test-resources` would be more suitable - jar files generated are kind of resources for these tests. Such configuration makes tests pass as well, but feels slightly better in terms of semantics.

`pom.xml` for `reef-runtime-multi` is not updated. The project has no code right now, but it still needs to be updated for future use.
I'll fix that and merge.
Thank you, @tcNickolas .
`generate-test-resources` sounds perfect for me, too. I'll update the code.
The PR is rebased and updated.

I'm not entirely sure how to solve the unchecked cast problem over serialization in this PR, any suggestions?

@afchung I've done a pass. This work is really great! Could you address some comments I left? Thanks!

@afchung The test org.apache.reef.tests.applications.vortex.addition.SumOnesTest.testVortexSumOnes fails in Jenkins. Could you check it?
@bgchun is there a way to get the log files on the machines? Would like to see if there is anything helpful there. Thanks!

@bgchun Actually, I've found and fixed the bug, which was caused by a race condition in `VortexAggregateFuture.hasNext()`. I've addressed the problem by splitting up `AggregateResult` into `AggregateResult` (which doesn't have `hasNext()`) and `AggregateResultSynchronous` (which has `hasNext()`).

@bgchun and @yunseong please have another look, thanks!
@yunseong I quickly looked through the code. Could you take another look?
The rebased PR passes `mvn clean test` for me
